questionOriginal: What is a coronavirus?
questionText: What is a coronavirus?
answerOriginal: Coronaviruses are a large family of viruses. There are different types of coronaviruses.  Some types of coronavirus are more common in people and some versions are more common in animals. Rarely, a type of the virus that was common in animals can spread to people. "Coronavirus Disease 2019” (which is shortened to "COVID-19") is an example of a type of coronavirus that has recently spread to humans.     [[Would you like more information about What is COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]] [[Would you like more information about What is novel (new) coronavirus?]]

questionOriginal: What is novel (new) coronavirus?
questionText: What is novel (new) coronavirus?
answerOriginal: A "novel" virus means that scientists haven't seen this type of the virus before.  "Coronavirus Disease 2019” which is shortened to "COVID-19" is type of a virus that has never been seen before in humans.  [[Would you like more information about What is COVID-19?]] [[Would you like more information about What is a coronavirus?]]  When our body has seen a virus before either through a previous infection or through a vaccine, the body's defense system known as the "immune system" remembers how to fight off the virus if it sees it again. Because our body has never seen this virus before, our body's immune system has to learn how to fight off this new type of virus. While some of the symptoms of COVID-19 overlap with "common" cold or flu symptoms, it is caused by a different virus.

questionOriginal: What is COVID-19?
questionText: What is COVID-19?
answerOriginal: COVID-19 is a disease caused by a new type of virus. Sometimes people also call it "coronavirus," which is is the type of virus that causes COVID-19. COVID-19 causes some symptoms that are like getting a cold or flu. But some people get worse symptoms and need more care. COVID-19 is caused by a new type of virus that our body has not seen before. Since our body has not seen it before, our immune system has to learn how to fight off this new virus.     [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: What is SARS-CoV-2?
questionText: What is SARS-CoV-2?
answerOriginal: SARS-COV-2 is the name for the virus that causes the disease known as "COVID-19." Let's break it down.  "SARS" stands for "Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome", meaning that it can cause serious problems with breathing and the lungs.    "COV" stands for "Coronavirus." This is the type of virus that causes COVID-19.   The "2" is a way to say that this virus is different than the SARS virus that caused an outbreak in 2002-2003. questionOriginal: What is MERS-CoV?
questionText: What is MERS-CoV?
answerOriginal: MERS-CoV is one type of coronavirus. It is different type from the type of coronavirus that causes COVID-19. MERS-CoV stands for "Middle East Respiratory Syndrome- associated Coronavirus."  The first cases of MERS-CoV were seen in 2012 in Saudi Arabia. MERS-CoV symptoms are fever, cough, and shortness of breath. People with this disease usually do not get sick from one another unless they are in very close contact. questionOriginal: What can I do to prevent getting COVID-19?
questionText: What can I do to prevent getting COVID-19?
answerOriginal: To prevent getting sick from COVID-19, the most important thing is to wash your hands. Use soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after blowing your nose, coughing, sneezing, using the restroom, or before or after eating or making food. ALWAYS wash your hands with soap and water if your hands look dirty. If you cannot wash your hands, use hand sanitizer that has at least 60 percent alcohol.     Here are some other things you can do to reduce your risk of getting COVID-19:    - Clean and disinfect surfaces that you touch a lot, like tables, counters, light switches, door knobs, and cabinet handles.   - Cover your coughs and sneezes with tissues and throw the tissue away.   - Stay at home if you are sick.   - Don't get too close to people who are sick.   - If "social distancing" measures are in effect where you are, be sure to follow them.     [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]   [[Would you like more information about What is social distancing?]]

questionOriginal: What is a virus?
questionText: What is a virus?
answerOriginal: A virus is the smallest of infectious microbes, smaller than bacteria or fungi. A virus consists of a small piece of genetic material (DNA or RNA) surrounded by a protein shell. Viruses cannot survive without a living cell in which to reproduce. Once a virus enters a living cell (the host cell) and takes over a cell's inner workings, the cell cannot carry out its normal life-sustaining tasks. The host cell becomes a virus manufacturing plant, making viral parts that then reassemble into whole viruses and go on to infect other cells.

questionOriginal: Why is COVID-19 dangerous?
questionText: Why is COVID-19 dangerous?
answerOriginal: COVID-19 is currently a global pandemic. Around 1 out of every 6 people who gets COVID-19 becomes seriously ill and develops difficulty breathing. This disease targets older people, and those with underlying medical problems like high blood pressure, heart problems or diabetes. What makes COVID-19 dangerous is that there is still very little known about it, including no effective treatment, and it is spreading rapidly in communities.

questionOriginal: Is the virus manufactured or naturally occuring?
questionText: Is the virus manufactured or naturally occuring?
answerOriginal: Coronaviruses are a large family of viruses that are common in people and many different species of animals, including camels, cattle, cats, and bats. Rarely, animal coronaviruses can infect people and then spread between people such as with MERS-CoV, SARS-CoV, and now with this new virus (named SARS-CoV-2). The analysis of public genome sequence data from SARS-CoV-2 and related viruses found no evidence that the virus was made in a laboratory or otherwise engineered.
answerText: Coronaviruses are a large family of viruses that are common in people and many different species of animals, including camels, cattle, cats, and bats. Rarely, animal coronaviruses can infect people and then spread between people such as with MERS-CoV, SARS-CoV, and now with this new virus (named SARS-CoV-2). The analysis of public genome sequence data from SARS-CoV-2 and related viruses found no evidence that the virus was made in a laboratory or otherwise engineered.

questionOriginal: What is the difference between a bacteria and a virus?
questionText: What is the difference between a bacteria and a virus?
answerOriginal: The major differences between bateria and viruses are that bacteria are more complex; they can reproduce on their own; they can survive in different environments, including extreme heat and cold, radioactive waste, and the human body; and most bacteria are harmless.   Viruses, on the other hand, are much smaller; they can’t survive or reproduce without a host, and most viruses do cause disease. They’re quite specific about the cells they attack. For example, certain viruses attack cells in the liver, respiratory system, or blood. In some cases, viruses target bacteria.

questionOriginal: Why are the death rates so different across countries?
questionText: Why are the death rates so different across countries?
answerOriginal: The lack of widespread, systematic testing in most countries is the main source of discrepancies in death rates internationally. If some countries are only testing those patients who are sick enough to go to the hospital, and are not testing those who are not as sick, not showing symptoms, and who are not getting to the hospital, that affects death rates. Death rates can appear to be higher in countries where testing is more widespread. Plus, causes of death might be uncertain for those patients who have underlying conditions.

questionOriginal: Where do I go if I have mild symptoms?
questionText: Where do I go if I have mild symptoms?
answerOriginal: Stay home!  Most people with COVID-19 have mild illness and are able to recover at home without medical care. Do not leave your home, except to get medical care. questionOriginal: What are respiratory droplets?
questionText: What are respiratory droplets?
answerOriginal: They are any types of secretions that come from your nose and mouth. This could include droplets released when you sneeze, cough, or talk. Respiratory droplets may also be passed from person-to-person through commonly used surfaces such as door knobs, elevator buttons and faucets.  [[Would you like more information on how you can avoid getting infected with the virus that causes COVID-19?]] Socially distancing is a practice that aims to prevent those who are sick from coming into contact with those who are healthy. This is to reduce the opportunity for disease transmission. It means avoiding crowds, mass gatherings, and maintaining at least a 6 foot physical distance from others. This means no handshakes, hugs, or high-fives. It is also important to practice frequent hand-washing with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. If soap is not available, you may use an alcohol-based (at least 60%) hand sanitizer.

questionOriginal: Can COVID-19 be transmitted when a person is not showing symptoms?
questionText: Can COVID-19 be transmitted when a person is not showing symptoms?
answerOriginal: People are thought to be most contagious when they are most symptomatic and are feeling the sickest. Some spread might be possible before people show symptoms and realize they are sick. There have been reports of this occurring with this new coronavirus, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads.. Canada public health services is currently investigating into this question further.

questionOriginal: Does COVID-19 transfer through the air?
questionText: Does COVID-19 transfer through the air?
answerOriginal: Droplet transmission occurs when a person is in in close contact  with someone who is infected and is therefore at risk of having his/her mouth, nose or eyes exposed to potentially infected respiratory droplets. Transmission may also occur through frequently touched or exposed surfaces that carry viral droplets, though this is less common.  Airborne transmission is different from droplet transmission. In the context of COVID-19, airborne transmission may be possible in specific circumstances such as medical procedures like intubation that generate a lot of aerosols. One recent study found COVID-19 virus in aerosol particles up to 3 hours in laboratory conditions. However, laboratory conditions can differ from real world conditions so in nature, respiratory droplets sink to the ground faster than the aerosols produced in this study. The experimental aerosols used in labs are smaller than what comes out of a cough or sneeze, so they remain in the air at face-level longer than heavier particles would in nature.

questionOriginal: How long does the virus live on surfaces, like packages, plastic, etc? Should we be worried about that?
questionText: How long does the virus live on surfaces, like packages, plastic, etc? Should we be worried about that?
answerOriginal: A recent study shows that in laboratory conditions, the virus can live in the air and on surfaces from several hours to several days. On plastic, it can live for up to 72 hours (3 days). On stainless steel, it can live for up to 48 hours (2 days). On cardboard, it can live up to 24 hours (1 day). On copper, it can live up to four hours. It is detectable in the air for up to three hours. However, the amount of infectious virus that remains reduces with time - making contracting COVID-19 from these surfaces theoretically possible but unlikely. Additionally, this was determined from laboratory conditions and may not reflect real world conditions.   It is still important to regularly clean and disinfect high-touch surfaces. Remember to wash your hands frequently with soap and water or an alcohol based hand sanitizer (60%).

questionOriginal: What is community spread?

answerOriginal: Community spread means people have been infected with the virus in an area, including some who are not sure how or where they became infected.

questionOriginal: What is "flattening the curve"?
questionText: What is "flattening the curve"?
answerOriginal: Flattening the curve refers to the use of socially distancing to prevent surges in the number of people who are infected wiith an illness in order to prevent the healthcare system from being overwhelmed.
answerText: Flattening the curve refers to the use of socially distancing to prevent surges in the number of people who are infected wiith an illness in order to prevent the healthcare system from being overwhelmed.

questionOriginal: Why do I have to "socially distance"?
questionText: Why do I have to "socially distance"?
answerOriginal: Social distancing is deliberately increasing the physical space between people to avoid spreading illness from someone who is sick but may not realize it yet to someone who is healthy. Staying at least six feet away from other people lessens your chances of catching COVID-19 since it primarily spread from person-to-person interactions.  Social distancing is especially important to reduce the chance of infection amongst populations that are more vulnerable to severe diseaase. Social distancing helps stop the virus from spreading quickly, which helps reduce the burden on healthcare systems and workers, as there are not enough workers and beds to care for patients if everyone were to have COVID-19 at the same time. Examples of socially distancing include: avoiding non-essential gatherings, avoiding crowded places such as concerts, arenas, conferences and festivals, limiting contact with people at higher risk like older adults and those in poor health and keeping a distance of at least 2 arms-length (approximately 6 feet) from others.

questionOriginal: What is self-isolation?
questionText: What is self-isolation?
answerOriginal: Self-isolation means that people who are sick stay away from those who are not sick. This helps to keep the disease from spreading. If someone has asked you to self-isolate, you should:  -Stay at home except to get medical care -Stay away from other people in your home as much as you can -Wear a face mask if you have to be around other people (for example, in a doctor's office) -Cover your coughs and sneezes -Wash your hands a lot -Keep track of your symptoms  Go here to read more about how you should self-isolate, visit this page: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/steps-when-sick.html   [[Would you like more information about What is social-distancing?]] [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: What is self-monitoring?
questionText: What is self-monitoring?
answerOriginal: This means that people should monitor themselves for fever by taking their temperatures twice a day, and pay attention to if they begin coughing or have difficulty breathing. If they begin to develop symptoms during this self-monitoring period, they should self-isolate, limit their contact with others, and seek medical advice by telephone if possible.

questionOriginal: What's the difference between self-isolating and self-monitoring?
questionText: What's the difference between self-isolating and self-monitoring?
answerOriginal: The difference between self-monitoring and self-isolation is based on whether you have been diagnosed with COVID-19 or not. You need to self-monitor if you have no symptoms but may have been exposed to COVID-19 in the last 14 days or are in close contact with older adults, people who are medically vulnerable or have been asked to do so by your Public Health Authority. Self-monitoring means to monitor yourself for 14 days for symptoms of respiratory illness, such as fever, cough, and difficulty breathing and to stay at home, avoid crowded places, increase your personal space from others by at least 6 feet whenever possible and to continue practice good hand hygiene. Self-isolation is appropriate for people who are confirmed to have COVID-19. Isolation is a health care term that means keeping people who are infected with a contagious illness away from those who are not infected. If you have been asked to self-isolate, please avoid leaving your home except to get medical care, separate yourself from other people in your home to the extent possible, wear a face mask if you are around other people (for example, in a doctor's office), cover your coughs and sneezes, wash your hands frequently and continue to monitor your symptoms until your healthcare provider says you no longer need to be in isolation.

questionOriginal: What is social distancing?
questionText: What is social distancing?
answerOriginal: Social distancing means staying home and limiting contact with other people as much as you can. Social distancing is important because it reduces the spread of illness. You might need to change your habits to do social distancing well. For example:  -Avoid groups of people as much as you can -Don't shake hands or touch people to greet them -Don't go to crowded places such as concerts, arenas, conferences, or festivals -Stay away from people at high risk for severe symptoms, such as older people and those in poor health -Stay at least 2 arms' length (about 6 feet) away from others.  For example, if you need to buy groceries, limit this to once a week. If you go on walks, stay at least 6 feet away from others.

questionOriginal: Can we use fabric masks to prevent the spread?
questionText: Can we use fabric masks to prevent the spread?
answerOriginal: Face masks, including fabric ones, are only really helpful in preventing people who have coronavirus (COVID-19) from spreading it to others. If the person is healthy, there is likely no need for them to wear a mask - as there is little evidence showing that these masks used by healthy people will prevent transmission to the public.  What masks can be useful in for the general public is reducing the amount of times a person touches their face, which means less opportunity for COVID-19 to enter their body. This is because the mask is covering a significant amount of a person's face (namely the mouth and nose). This is the most effective practice when used in combination with frequent hand-washing with soap and water, or with an alcohol-based hand sanitizer.  However, these is a shortage of available face masks for health workers - which is dangerous as they are on the frontlines of this pandemic.   [[Would you like more information about face masks?]] There are currently not enough face masks for health workers to use, which is dangerous as they are on the frontlines of this pandemic. This ranges from basic surgical masks to respirator masks. Health workers are also being asked to reuse them. This situation makes health workers vulnerable to becoming infected with COVID-19. If you have a surplus of face masks, it is currently recommended to donate that to your local healthcare facility. There have also been call to actions for individuals to create fabric face masks, which can be reusable, to donate to local healthcare facilities.

questionOriginal: What are N95 respirators/masks?
questionText: What are N95 respirators/masks?
answerOriginal: This is a type of personal protective equipment that forms a tight seal around the nose and mouth to avoid airborne particles and fluid from entering. These masks are not "one size fits all" so people who depend on them for the job must get fit-tested prior to using them.

questionOriginal: What is personal protective equipment (PPE)?
questionText: What is personal protective equipment (PPE)?
answerOriginal: Personal protective equipment (PPE) are types of equipment worn to minimize exposure to hazards that can cause workplace injuries or illness. Examples include gloves, safety glasses, shoes, earplugs or muffs, hard hats, respirators, coveralls, etc. This is coming up significantly during this pandemic because there is a shortage of face masks available for frontline health workers.

questionOriginal: Is COVID-19 contagious? Can someone who has it spread it to others? (How contagious is the virus?)

questionOriginal: How long are you contagious for if you have COVID-19?
questionText: How long are you contagious for if you have COVID-19?
answerOriginal: How long you are contagious for varies as decisions about when one can be released from isolation are made on a case-by-case basis. You should consult your healthcare provider to decide when you may be released from isolation. If you have been released from isolation, then you are no longer considered to pose a risk of infection to others. Generally, your doctor will be looking for signs that the patient is free from fever without the use of fever-reducing medications, the patient is no longer showing symptoms,  and based on the severity of the patient's illness, your doctor may recommend testing respiratory samples.

questionOriginal: What is the difference between isolation and quarantine?
questionText: What is the difference between isolation and quarantine?
answerOriginal: Isolation refers to separating people who are known to be sick from those who are healthy to limit the spread of a disease. questionOriginal: What does it mean to be isolated if you live with other people?
questionText: What does it mean to be isolated if you live with other people?
answerOriginal: If the infected person lives with others, it'll be important that they stay in another room, or be separated from others as much as possible. Preferably, they should have a separate bedroom and bathroom if that is available. Prohibit visitors who do not have an essential need to be in the home. The infected person should not care for any pets in the home. Hand wash regularly with soap and water or with a hand sanitizer that contains 60-95% alcohol. Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands. Avoid sharing household items (like dishes, cups, towels, bedding) with the infected person. Clean and disinfect high touch surfaces regularly. Wash laundry thoroughly and frequently.

questionOriginal: What is self-quarantine?
questionText: What is self-quarantine?
answerOriginal: Quarantine means staying away from other people because you might have been exposed to the virus. For COVID-19, people should quarantine for at least 14 days, or 2 weeks from the time they might have had contact with someone with COVID-19. That's because most people who get COVID-19 would have symptoms within 14 days.   Scientist think that people are not likely to spread COVID-19 to others if they do not get sick after 14 days.

questionOriginal: Can COVID-19 be spread through food (including refrigerated or frozen food)?
questionText: Can COVID-19 be spread through food (including refrigerated or frozen food)?
answerOriginal: Right now, our current understanding of how COVID-19 spreads is primarily through person-to-person transfer of respiratory droplets. Studies are being conducted to understand how long Coronavirus lives on surfaces. In general, it is best to practice good food hygiene and good food safety practices. This means cleaning frequently used surfaces often, cleaning your fruits and vegetables, and cooking meats well. It is also important for all household members to wash hands frequently with soap and water before handling food.

questionOriginal: Can COVID-19 be spread through surface-touching?
questionText: Can COVID-19 be spread through surface-touching?
answerOriginal: Recent studies show in laboratories, COVID-19 can last on surfaces. However, with time, the amount of infectious virus decreases. So, it is possible that if someone touches a surface that has the virus on it and then touch their mouth, nose, or eyes that they can get the infection. However, this is thought to be less common than acquiring it through the transfer of respiratory droplets between two people.

questionOriginal: Will warm weather / summer / heat stop outbreak of COVID-19?
questionText: Will warm weather / summer / heat stop outbreak of COVID-19?
answerOriginal: We do not know. Some viruses, like the common cold or flu, spread more optimally during the cold weather months but people still become sick in warmer months with them. There is still a lot to learn about how weather and temperature impact spread of COVID-19.

questionOriginal: Should I wear a mask?
questionText: Should I wear a mask?
answerOriginal: Face masks, including fabric ones, are helpful in preventing people who have coronavirus (COVID-19) from spreading it to others. If you are experiencing symptoms of COVID-19, it might be helpful to wear a mask if you are around household members. Masks can be useful for the general public is reducing the amount of times a person touches their face, which means less opportunity for COVID-19 to enter their body. This is because the mask is covering a significant amount of a person's face (namely the mouth and nose). In several countries, health care workers are experiencing a shortage of masks as the virus spreads. If there are mask shortages in your country, you may consider the use of home-made cloth masks or a scraf as a face covering.

questionOriginal: Is six feet a best practice, or is that a 100% safe zone?

answerOriginal: Close contact with other people means being within six feet of each other. However, this does not mean that if you maintain a six foot difference from everyone, you will not get the virus.

questionOriginal: Will herd immunity be the only means of controlling COVID-19?
questionText: Will herd immunity be the only means of controlling COVID-19?
answerOriginal: No, herd immunity is not the only way to control COVID-19.   Herd immunity refers to when enough of the population is immune to an infectious disease (either through vaccinations and/or prior illness) that it makes it difficult for the disease to spread person to person. For COVID-19, that would mean that enough people develop immunity after acquiring the infection and reduce the person-to-person spread. However, if too many people become sick with COVID-19 at once, that will lead to more hospitalizations, an overburdened healthcare system, and more deaths. There is also still a lot that we do not know about COVID-19, including how long the immunity lasts.   Right now, it is best to practice social distancing, stay at home as much as possible, and practice frequent hand-washing with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. If you do have to go out, maintain a 6 foot distance between yourself and others.

questionOriginal: Does hand-washing kill the virus?
questionText: Does hand-washing kill the virus?
answerOriginal: Hand-washing is one of the best ways to protect yourself and your family from getting sick. Use soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after blowing your nose, coughing, sneezing, using the restroom, or before or after eating or making food. ALWAYS wash your hands after you have been in a public place and touched items that are frequently touched by other people (e.g. door handles, tables). Diligent hand-washing can remove all tarces of the virus on your hands. If you cannot wash your hands, use hand sanitizer that has at least 60 percent alcohol. Sanitizers do not get rid of all types of germs.

questionOriginal: Can a person test negative and later test positive for COVID-19?
questionText: Can a person test negative and later test positive for COVID-19?
answerOriginal: In general, a negative result means that the virus that causes COVID-19 was not found in the sample collected. However, sometimes if a person has COVID-19 in the early stages, it is possible that an initial test is negative but a test is positive later on when there is more virus present. You healthcare provider can help decide if you should be retested.

answerOriginal: Chloroquine Phosphate is a medicine that people usually use to prevent or treat malaria. As of April 2020, it has not been approved to treat COVID-19. questionOriginal: How do you put on, use, take off, and dispose of a face mask?
questionText: How do you put on, use, take off, and dispose of a face mask?
answerOriginal: First, please remember that face masks should only be used by health workers, caretakers, and individuals who are exhibiting symptoms (e.g. cough, fever).   1. Before touching the mask, washing your hands with soap and water or an alcohol-based hand sanitizer. 2. Take the mask and inspect it for tears and holes. 3. Orient which side is the top side (which is where the metal strip is) 4. Ensure that the proper side of the mask is facing outwards (the colored side) 5. Place the mask to your face. Pinch the metal strip or the stiff edge of the mask so it molds to the shape of your nose. 6. Pull down the bottom of the mask so it is covering your mouth and chin 7. After use, take the mask off - remove the elastic loops from behind your ears, while keeping the mask away from your face and clothes. This is to avoid touching potentially contaminated surfaces of the mask 8. Discard the mask in a closed trash can immediately after use 9. Wash your hands with soap and water or an alcohol-based hand sanitizer after touching / discarding the mask.

questionOriginal: Should people avoid products shipped from China?
questionText: Should people avoid products shipped from China?
answerOriginal: Given that the virus has spread all over the world, there is no reason to be more concerned about a product that shipped from China compared to anywhere elsse. Coronaviruses may be transmitted by touching a surface, but they are more likely to be transmitted through droplets. Overtime, the amount of infectious virus on a surface decreases. You can always wipe down any packages you may receive, allow a few days to pass before opening the package, and wash your hands with soap and water after touching packages.

questionOriginal: How can I and my family prepare for COVID-19?
questionText: How can I and my family prepare for COVID-19?

questionOriginal: What can I do to reduce my and my family's risk of getting COVID-19?
questionText: What can I do to reduce my and my family's risk of getting COVID-19?
answerOriginal: You can reduce your risk of getting sick by staying at home as much as possibe and only going out whenever absolutely essential. If you do go out, you should try and maintain a 6 foot distance between you and other people. If you are sick, stay at home, except when getting medical care, until your doctor says you no longer have to stay home. Cover your coughs and sneezes with tissues, and throw the tissue away. Wash your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after blowing your nose, coughing, sneezing, using the restroom, coming home and before eating or preparing food. If you don't have soap and water, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that has at least 60% alcohol. ALWAYS wash your hands with soap and water if your hands are visibly dirty. Please also clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces (e.g. tables, countertops, light switches, door knobs, cabinet handles).

questionOriginal: What if someone in my house gets sick with COVID-19?
questionText: What if someone in my house gets sick with COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Most people who get COVID-19 will be able to recover at home. If you are sick, stay at home except when you need to get medical care. If you experience difficulty breathing or shortness of breath, persistent pain or pressure in the chest, new confusion or inability to arouse, bluish lips or face, or any other concerns, please seek medical attention immediately. Please keep in mind that this is not the full list and if you're experiencing severe symptoms or something you are concerned by, please contact your medical provider.   If possible, use a separate room and bathroom for the sick household member. Try to have the sick family member maintain distance as much as possible. It will be important to make sure you clean and sanitize your hands and home regularly.  Avoid sharing personal items like utensils, foods, and drinks.

questionOriginal: What should I do if there is an outbreak in my community?
questionText: What should I do if there is an outbreak in my community?
answerOriginal: It is important to stay calm and put your preparedness plan into action. Please stay home if you are sick, and limit contact with others as much as possible (with at least a 6 feet distance between you and another person). It is important to stay informed about the local COVID-19 situation through local health department. Please continue to practice handwashing, cover your coughs and sneezes with tissue, and frequently clean high-touch surfaces with regular household detergent and water.   It is important to also notify your workplace ASAP if your regular work schedule will need to change. Ask to work from home or take leave if your or someone in your home gets sick with COVID-19 symptoms or if your child's school is dismissed.   If you live alone and have a chronic health condition, please reach out to friends, family, loved ones, and healthcare providers. Also ask them to check in on you.   Please also stay in touch with loved ones by phone or email. This can be a lonely and isolating time, so it is important to practice self-care as well as reach out to others.

Please also stay in touch with loved ones by phone or email. This can be a lonely and isolating time, so it is important to practice self-care as well as reach out to others.

questionOriginal: How long should we self quarantine before moving into our elderly parents’ house? (Where we will continue to self quarantine)
questionText: How long should we self quarantine before moving into our elderly parents’ house? (Where we will continue to self quarantine)

questionOriginal: How can I protect myself and others?
questionText: How can I protect myself and others?
answerOriginal: The most important action you can take is to frequiently wash your hands. Wash your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after blowing your nose, coughing, sneezing, using the restroom, and before eating or preparing food. If you don't have soap and water, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that has at least 60% alcohol. ALWAYS wash your hands with soap and water if your hands are visibly dirty. Please also clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces (e.g. tables, countertops, light switches, door knobs, cabinet handles). Also avoid close contact with those who are sick. When you are sick, stay at home - except when getting medical care. Cover your coughs and sneezes with tissues, and throw the tissue away. If 'social distancing' measures have been recommended where you are, be certain to follow them.  [[Would you like more information about "What are COVID-19 symptoms?"]]

questionOriginal: Should I use soap and water or a hand sanitizer to protect against COVID-19?
questionText: Should I use soap and water or a hand sanitizer to protect against COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Handwashing with soap and water for at least 20 seconds is the best way to protect yourself and your family from getting sick! This is important to do regularly - every time you wash your hands - but especially after blowing your nose, coughing, sneezing, going to the restroom, and before eating or preparing food. If you do not have soap and water available, please use an alcohol based hand sanitizer that has at least 60% alcohol.

questionOriginal: Should I stay home and even avoid going to the supermarket and drugstore?
questionText: Should I stay home and even avoid going to the supermarket and drugstore?
answerOriginal: Yes, you can go to the supermarket and drugstore whenever absolutely necessary, but it is important to go during off-peak hours when less people will be there. It is also important to go as few times as possible to these locations so try and make a thorough list ahead of time so you do not forget any supplies.

questionOriginal: What are COVID-19 symptoms?
questionText: What are COVID-19 symptoms?
answerOriginal: The most common symptoms of COVID-19 are fever, feeling tired, and dry cough. Some patients may also have aches and pains, stuffy nose, runny nose, sore throat, or diarrhea  Most people have mild symptoms that get worse slowly. Most people start to feel sick between 1 and 14 days after being exposed to COVID-19.Some people get infected but don't feel sick at all.  Older people (those who are 65 or older) and people with health problems like diabetes, high blood pressure, or heart problems are more likely to get very sick from COVID-19.  If you or someone you know has one of these problems, you should call a doctor or go to the emergency room RIGHT NOW:  -Pain or pressure in the chest that doesn't go away -Starting to feel confused -Can't wake up from sleeping -Lips or face look blue  If someone has one of these severe symptoms, they need care right away.  [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk for severe illness?]]

questionText: What are the complications from Covid-19?
answerOriginal: Complications from COVID-19 include pneumonia in both lungs, organ failure in several organs, and death.

questionOriginal: How likely am I to catch COVID-19?
questionText: How likely am I to catch COVID-19?
answerOriginal: It depends on where you are, and if there is a COVID-19 outbreak happening there. Right now, in most locations, the risk of catching COVID-19 is still low but it is rapidly developing in many cities and areas around the world. If you are not sure that an outbreak if happening in your community, please check out the COVID-19 map: https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/map.html  [[Would you like more information about how to protect yourself and your family during this time?]]

questionOriginal: Is Covid same as the flu?
questionText: Is Covid same as the flu?
answerOriginal: The symptoms of COVID-19 and flu are very similar. Both can cause fever, cough, and shortness of breath. To know for sure if you have COVID-19, you need to have a test from a doctor.   [[Would you like more information about What are COVID-19 symptoms?]]

questionOriginal: What should I do if I think I was exposed to someone with COVID?
questionText: What should I do if I think I was exposed to someone with COVID?
answerOriginal: If you think you had contact with someone with COVID-19, you should quarantine yourself for at least 14 days (or two weeks) so that you don't spread the disease. Most people who get sick from COVID-19 get symptoms 1 to 14 days after being exposed. If you have any symptoms related to COVID-19, you should self-isolate and talk to your health care provider. questionOriginal: Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?
questionText: Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?
answerOriginal: People are more likely to get a severe case of COVID-19 if they are:  -Older than 65 years old -Living in a nursing home or long term care facility -Pregnant -In a prison or jail  People are also more likely to get a severe case if they have a health problem such as:  -Lung disease -Asthma -Diabetes -Sickle cell disease -Liver cirrhosis (liver scarring) -Recent chemotherapy -A weaker immune system   [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of getting COVID-19?]]

questionOriginal: Can my child get sick from Covid?
questionText: Can my child get sick from Covid?
answerOriginal: From what doctors know now, children are not at a higher risk of Covid-19 than adults. Children can become sick with it, but not as often as adults. Most children who have gotten sick with COVID-19 have had mild symptoms, like fever, runny nose, and cough. Some have also had vomiting and diarrhea.  We are still learning if children with some underlying medical conditions may have a higher risk.  [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?]]

questionOriginal: Are symptoms of COVID-19 different in children?
questionText: Are symptoms of COVID-19 different in children?
answerOriginal: No. They have the same symptoms, though it may be milder in children. Reported symptoms include cold-like symptoms, such as fever, runny nose, and cough. Vomiting and diarrhea have also been reported. There is more to be learned about how COVID-19 affects children.

questionOriginal: How do I prepare my child for a COVID-19 outbreak?
questionText: How do I prepare my child for a COVID-19 outbreak?
answerOriginal: It is important to talk with your child about what's going on. This is a stressful time for both children and adults, and children definitely will have questions. Talk to them about the outbreak, stay calm, and reassure them that they are safe. If it is appropriate, emphasize that most illness from COVID-19 seems to be mild.

questionOriginal: What steps should parents take to protect children during a community outbreak?
questionText: What steps should parents take to protect children during a community outbreak?
answerOriginal: Remember - this is a new virus, and there is a lot we don't know. Currently, there has not been a lot of illness occurring in children. Most of the illnesses that are occuring are in adults of working age and older adults (over the age 65).   If your child/children become sick with COVID-19, let their child care facility or school know. Talk with teachers about their classroom assignments and how your child/children can continue work from home and keep up with school work.   It is also important to discourage your children from gathering in crowds or in public places, and emphasize the importance of keeping distance from others. This is to help slow spread of COVID-19.

questionOriginal: I am pregnant, am I at a greater risk for more serious outcomes related to COVID-19?
questionText: I am pregnant, am I at a greater risk for more serious outcomes related to COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Doctors don't yet know for sure if pregnant women have a higher risk of having severe symptoms or long-term effects if they get COVID-19. questionOriginal: I'm currently giving birth at a hospital in several weeks. Are there things that I should clean myself just in case? Also should I bring my own pillow and sheets for the hospital bed?
questionText: I'm currently giving birth at a hospital in several weeks. Are there things that I should clean myself just in case? Also should I bring my own pillow and sheets for the hospital bed?
answerOriginal: No, you do not have to bring your pillow and sheets for the hospital bed, as the hospital will ensure that everything is clean and sanitized. However, it is important that you are aware of certain policies hospitals are beginning to administer. For example, some hospitals are not allowing any visitors - which means your loved one, doula, etc will not be able to be beside you as you give birth. Please call your healthcare provider to get more information.   [[Would you like more information about what do I do if I've tested positive for COVID-19 and am about to deliver?]]

questionOriginal: Can my dog/cat/pet/animal get COVID-19?
questionText: Can my dog/cat/pet/animal get COVID-19?
answerOriginal: While this virus did emerge from an animal source, it is only passing person-to-person currently. Currently, there is no evidence that shows a pet can become sick with COVID-19... but animals can spread disease to people, and people can spread disease to animals. So it is important to always wash your hands before and after interacting with animals.

questionOriginal: Can I get COVID-19 from animals when travelling to other countries?
questionText: Can I get COVID-19 from animals when travelling to other countries?
answerOriginal: Although the current spread and growth of the COVID-19 outbreak is primarily associated with spread from person to person, experts agree that the virus likely originated from bats and may have passed through an intermediary animal source (currently unknown) in China before being transmitted to humans.  It is recommended that individuals who travel to avoid contact with animals, including wild meat and wet (live animal) markets.  If you are considering travel, check the latest travel health notices for the most up-to-date travel advice prior to travelling.  Importers, rescue organizations and adoptive families should limit or postpone importing animals from affected areas. If animals are imported from an affected area: they should be closely monitored for signs of illness, you should contact a veterinarian if they become sick, and call ahead to ensure they are aware of the circumstances

questionOriginal: Can my pet or other animals get sick from COVID-19?
questionText: Can my pet or other animals get sick from COVID-19?
answerOriginal: It is possible that some types of animals can be infected with COVID-19 but there is no evidence that pets or other animals can spread the virus. There are still many unknowns about COVID-19 and this is an area that remains to be studied and understood.  Until we know more, if you have been diagnosed with COVID-19 and have a pet or other animal: avoid close contact with them, do not snuggle or kiss them, or let them lick you, sit on your lap, or sleep in your bed, practice good cough etiquette, avoid coughing and sneezing on your animals, have another member of your household care for your animals (if this is not possible, always wash your hands before touching or feeding them), and limit your animal's contact with other people and animals (this may mean keeping them indoors)  To date, there have not been any reports of livestock being infected by COVID-19 anywhere. However, livestock producers should follow normal biosecurity measures as always. This includes limiting visitors or workers who may have travelled to, or been in contact with, someone from an affected area.
answerText: It is possible that some types of animals can be infected with COVID-19 but there is no evidence that pets or other animals can spread the virus. There are still many unknowns about COVID-19 and this is an area that remains to be studied and understood.  Until we know more, if you have been diagnosed with COVID-19 and have a pet or other animal: avoid close contact with them, do not snuggle or kiss them, or let them lick you, sit on your lap, or sleep in your bed, practice good cough etiquette, avoid coughing and sneezing on your animals, have another member of your household care for your animals (if this is not possible, always wash your hands before touching or feeding them), and limit your animal's contact with other people and animals (this may mean keeping them indoors)  To date, there have not been any reports of livestock being infected by COVID-19 anywhere. However, livestock producers should follow normal biosecurity measures as always. This includes limiting visitors or workers who may have travelled to, or been in contact with, someone from an affected area.

questionOriginal: Should I avoid traveling?
questionText: Should I avoid traveling?
answerOriginal: If you are thinking about traveling, check the latest travel health notices for the most up-to-date travel advice before you go. It is important to limit travel as much as possible.   If you think you need to travel, please go through these questions:   1. Is COVID-19 spreading in the area where you're going?  If it is, you may be more likely to get infected if you travel there than if you stay at home.   2. Will you or the people who you are traveling with be in close contact with others during your trip?  Your risk increases in crowded settings, especially closed-in settings that do not have good circulation. This includes conferences, concerts, etc.   3. Are you or your travel companion more likely to get severe illness if you get COVID-19?  People at higher risk for severe disease are older adults and people of any age with serious chronic medical conditions (e.g. heart disease, lung disease, diabetes). If you are at higher risk, avoid all cruise travel and non-essential air travel.   4. Do you have a plan for taking time off from work or school, in case you are told to stay home for 14 days for self-monitoring or if you get sick with COVID-19?  You may be asked to take time off, and be unable to go to work or school until you are considered non-infectious.   5. Do you live with someone who is older or has a serious, chronic medical condition?  If you get sick with COVID-19 while you travel, your family, friends, loved ones may be at risk of getting sick. People who are older and who have health problems are more likely to get very sick.  6. Is COVID-19 spreading where I live when I return from travel?  Even if you don't feel sick right now, you could pass on COVID-19 to others during travel without knowing it. This is very important if you'll be in contact with people who are older adults or have a severe chronic health problem. These people are at higher risk of getting very sick.   It is important to go through these questions to decide if it makes sense to travel.  [[Would you like more information about Who is at a higher risk of severe illness?]] [[Would you like more information about Is there Covid in my area?]]

questionOriginal: What should I do if I just returned from a trip?
questionText: What should I do if I just returned from a trip?
answerOriginal: If you do not have any symptoms, you will be asked to do the following:  1. Self-quarantine for 14 days upon your return home. This means staying home and keeping your distance from others. 2. Do not have any visitors, especially older adults, or those with medical conditions who are higher risk of developing serious illness. 3. Monitor your health for fever, cough, or difficulty breathing. 4. Wash you hand frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, or use an alcohol based hand sanitizer. 5. Cover your mouth and nose with your arm or a tissue when coughing or sneezing. Dispose of tissue immediately, and wash your hands.   If you start to exhibit symptoms (e.g. cough, fever, difficulty breathing) within the 14 days:  1. Continue to self-isolate yourself from others.  2. Call a healthcare professional or a public health authority and describe your symptoms and travel history. Follow their instructions carefully.  3.  If your symptoms are severe - like you are having persistent pain/pressure in chest, new confusion or inability to arouse, or bluish lips or face, contact healthcare provider or go to the emergency room - it is important to seek care immediately.

questionOriginal: Can i go to the funeral of someone who died of COVID-19?
questionText: Can i go to the funeral of someone who died of COVID-19?
answerOriginal: Right now, there is currently no known risk with being in the same room at a funeral or visitation service with the body of someone who has died of COVID-19. That being said, currently, we all must avoid large gatherings and stay at home as much as possible.
answerText: Right now, there is currently no known risk with being in the same room at a funeral or visitation service with the body of someone who has died of COVID-19. That being said, currently, we all must avoid large gatherings and stay at home as much as possible.

questionOriginal: Am I at risk if I touch someone who has died of COVID-19 after they have passed away?
questionText: Am I at risk if I touch someone who has died of COVID-19 after they have passed away?
answerOriginal: Generally, do not touch the body of someone who has died of COVID-19.   We are still learning how COVID-19 spreads. Currently, we think the virus that causes COVID-19 is spreading from close contact with a person who has COVID-19 - likely through respiratory droplets that are produced when a sick person coughs or sneezes. This is like how the flu spreads. These droplets can land in the mouths or noses of nearby people, and inhaled into lungs. As such, it does not seem like this type of a spread will be that much of a concern after death.  That being said, one could get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it, and then touching their face (like their mouth, nose, or eyes). However, we do not think this is the main way in which this virus is being spread.   Older people (over the age of 65) and those with severe underlying health conditions are at higher risk of developing serious COVID-19 illness. There may be less of a chance of getting the illness by holding the hand or hugging the deceased body after it has been prepared for viewing. Other activities, such as kissing, washing, and shrouding should be avoided before, after, and during the body being prepared. If washing and shrouding the body are important cultural and religious practices, families should work with their community cultural and religious leaders as well as funeral home staff on how to reduce exposure as much as possible. It is recommended that those conducting these activities should wear disposable gloves. If fluid splashing is expected, additional personal protective equipment may be needed (like disposable gowns, goggles, face masks)

questionOriginal: What should I do if my family member dies of COVID-19 while overseas?
questionText: What should I do if my family member dies of COVID-19 while overseas?
answerOriginal: If a U.S. citizen dies outside the United States, that person's next of kin or legal representative should notify the US Consular officials at the Department of State. These people are available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, and provide assistance to US citizens for overseas emergencies.   If the family member, domestic partner, next of kin, or legal representative is in a different country than the deceased person, they should call the Department of State's Office of Overseas Citizens Services in Washington DC, from 8a-5p ET, Mon-Fri, at 888-407-4747 (toll-free) or 202-501-444. For emergency assistance after working hours or on weekends/holidays, call the Department of State switchboard at 202-647-4000 and ask to speak with the Overseas Citizens Services duty officer.   In addition to these steps above, the in-country of closest US embassy can also provide assistance.
answerText: If a U.S. citizen dies outside the United States, that person's next of kin or legal representative should notify the US Consular officials at the Department of State. These people are available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, and provide assistance to US citizens for overseas emergencies. questionOriginal: Why might someone blame or avoid individuals and groups because of COVID-19?
questionText: Why might someone blame or avoid individuals and groups because of COVID-19?
answerOriginal: There has been a rise in stigma and hate crimes against Chinese and other Asian Americans, as well as people who were in quarantine. This is due to lack of knowledge around how COVID-19 spreads, a need to blame someone, fears about disease and death, as well as gossip that spreads rumors and myths.  [[Would you like to know more about COVID 19's stigma?]] Stigma hurts everyone as it creates more fear and anger towards ordinary people, instead of the disease that is causing the problem, or towards systems that are not supporting people in accessing screening and treatment. Sharing facts about how COVID-19 actually spreads can help stop stigma.
